instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video output.
threads.message: All voltages are present except Thunderbolt. No video out through external or screen. Fan spins. CPU is on and warm. Everything seems good like it should be booting. No voltage going to display connector. Unfortunately I have no info on the board. I'm pretty sure it's a spill but there's no sign of damage anywhere. No sign of life if I plug a USB drive in. No lights. Not sure where to go next.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video output.
threads.message: Just saw that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is reading .020 in diode mode. 3.3V is measured though.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video output.
threads.message: Did you wait for the board to discharge before measuring <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>? What is resistance to GND on this bus in Ohm?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video output.
threads.message: It's at 24Ω. That number seems stable. Not moving at all. On a good board I'm seeing something in the range of 2.4kΩ.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video output.
threads.message: Well something is wrong on that bus, but EVERYTHING is on that bus. 24 Ohm is also not enough to heat something up. If you have no clue as to how this happened I'm afraid this board is a no fix.
